awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Predictive theory, synthesis and characterization of a new type of transparent conductor without doping
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description: Technologies such as photovoltaic solar cells, smart windows, light emitting diodes, touch-screen sensors, electronic papers, and flat panel displays require for their operation a critical component that is both an electrical conductor and optically transparent, the so-called transparent conductors. These compounds are unique, as transparency and conductivity are generally mutually exclusive properties of compounds. Indeed, optical transparency (as in window glass) is generally associated with electrical insulation, whereas electrical conductivity (such as in copper or gold) is generally associated with optically opaque metals. Known transparent conductors such as indium oxide doped with Sn are made by instilling conductivity in transparent insulators. The research team aims to develop a novel family of transparent conductors - metallic ceramics - by designing transparency in metals. This presents a new method to design optical properties as distinct from electronic properties. The approach has an exciting intellectual impact as it suggests a general approach for inverse design - starting from science-based design principles used as 'filters' for computational material selection, followed by identification of representative examples and then laboratory validation. The graduate students and postdocs of CU Boulder and Northwestern Universities are given exciting opportunities to participate in this cutting edge research effort. 

Technical description: Transparent conducting oxides are paradoxical materials that form the basis of modern day technologies, such as touch screens, flat panel displays, solar panels, etc. The current method of choice for discovering new transparent conductors have relied on heavily doping transparent insulators until they become conducting. Unfortunately, wide band gap materials are intrinsically resistant to doping of charges because of the existence of so-called 'doping bottlenecks'. Namely, the introduction of a high concentration of free carriers into insulators generally leads to the spontaneous formation of structural defects with polarity that compensate that of the intentional doping. Consequently, the progress in finding and optimizing such technologically critical transparent conducting oxide materials has been frustratingly slow. The research team proposes an opposite, and likely more fruitful alternative of designing transparency in metals by looking for compounds that obey a set of 'design principles' with specific band structures. The design rules for such intrinsic transparent conductors are: (i) identify a compound with metallic band structure; such that (ii) it has low plasma frequency and (iii) low inter-band optical absorption across the Fermi level, and (iv) apply synthesis and characterization to the 'best of class' compounds, here Ba-Nb-O. The most visible advantage of metallic transparent conductors is that their conductivity comes from their high, indigenous carrier concentration. The complex theory-experimental approach in the proposal enables more efficient progress as alternative to the previously used trial-and-error method.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The combination of seemly contraindicated material properties is commonly found to be essential for critical functionalities, such as the multiferroicity that starts from the explanation of the contraindication between magnetism and ferroelectricity followed by proposing practical routes to circumvent it. Transparent conductor combining optical transparency and electrical conductivity that are usually contraindicated due to the interaction between the electric carriers and incident light, lies at the center of many technological applications such as solar cells, touch screen sensors, light emitting diodes, electronic papers, photo detectors, smart windows and flat panel display. Materials with such functionality are generally made by starting with transparent insulator and making it conductive via heavy doping, an approach that generally faces severe "doping bottlenecks".

By avoiding the burden of heavy doping, we are tackling directly the problem whether optical transparency and electrical conductivity can coexist in the same pristine crystal. We started from a group of "degenerate insulators" with Fermi level inside the conduction band but with a sufficiently large internal band gap below the Fermi level followed by designing transparency by control of intrinsic interband optical transitions and intraband plasmonic frequencies. Our results demonstrate the coexistence of transparency and conductivity in a few degenerate insulators that are stable at ambient conditions against decomposition into their competing phases. Furthermore, we find that under certain growth conditions, the degenerate insulators have negative formation enthalpies for cation vacancies, leading to spontaneous non-stoichiometry and formation of characteristic ordered vacancy compounds. Our study provides insights into the stability of the transparent conductive states while pointing out that controllable formation of ordered vacancy compounds can be used to mitigate the notoriously difficult conflict between transparency and conductivity. This surprising prediction is validated in our key experimental finding where the synthesis of a degenerate insulator leads to several ordered vacancy compounds in the Ba-Nb-O system stabilized by effective reconstruction. In the meantime, our experimental results provide evidence for intrinsic semiconducting behavior of an all-metal heavy-atom transparent conductor TaIrGe predicted by us. We further discovered that the degenerate insulators could show antidoping where the doped band is shifted into the principal valence or conduction band, leading to increased band gap and reduced conductivity, which is a key factor to be considered in the design of transparent conductors. 

The coexistence of transparency and conductivity in degenerate insulators has guided us to the search of materials where generally contraindicated properties could coexist. We focused on the generally accepted unswitchable Dresselhaus spin splitting. The switchability of Rashba spin splitting in polar crystals induced by spin-orbit coupling via switching electric polarization is critic for spintronic devices, whereas the Dresselhaus spin splitting in nonpolar crystals such as GaAs is not switchable by symmetry. We proposed another type of Dresselhaus effect that exhibits spin splitting which is associated with the crystalline chirality. The special type of Dresselhaus spin splitting exists in a class of ferri-chiral crystals, which can be reversed upon a change in chirality. We find a stable ferri-chiral crystal with ultralow chiral phase transition barrier but rather large Dresselhaus spin splitting in the Na-Cu-S system. Such ferri-chiral crystal was synthesized in our experiments where both left-handed and right-handed structures as well as their domain walls were identified and characterized. We further studied the spin splitting in antiferromagnetic materials free from the requirement of relativistic spin-orbit coupling and revealed the role of nonmagnetic ligands in controlling the spin splitting magnitude.  

To date, the project has produced five peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in development. Several postdocs were trained in solid state physics, computational materials design, and optoelectronics. The PI gave a plenary talk on transparent conductors at the "International Workshop on Transparent Conducting Materials". The work on "spontaneous non-stoichiometry and ordering in degenerate but gapped transparent conductors" was published in the inaugural issue of the journal Matter.

Oleksandr I. Malyi, Michael T. Yeung, Kenneth R. Poeppelmeier, Clas Persson, and Alex Zunger. 2019. Spontaneous non-stoichiometry and ordering in degenerate but gapped transparent conductors. Matter, 1: 280-294. doi: 10.1016/j.matt.2019.05.014
